quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We have a head of AI operations. She's just constantly building prompts and building workflows that I and everyone else on the team are just automating as much as possible.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights an actionable org design pattern—dedicating a role to continuously create and maintain AI prompts/workflows to scale team leverage.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: I hate the headlines that are like, "Entry-level jobs are taken away by AI." Whenever I see a kid with ChatGPT, I'm like, "Holy shit, they're going to go so much faster than any other person that I've worked with."
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A contrarian take reframing AI as an accelerant for junior talent rather than a replacement, useful for hiring and training strategy.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: We have this guy, he made a year's worth of progress in two months because every time I sat down with him and told him, "Okay, here's how you tell a story, here's how you think about a headline," he recorded all of it, put it into a prompt, and he never made the same mistake twice.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete methodology for skill transfer: capture coaching, convert it into prompts, and use them as a persistent feedback loop to eliminate repeat errors.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: No one is manually coding anymore. Organizations like ours, people who are playing at the edge, we're doing things that, in three years, everybody else is going to be doing.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A memorable prediction/mental model for competitive advantage: early adopters operationalize AI-native workflows years before they become standard.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: AI reshoring American jobs
quotes.text: I think that AI may be one of the biggest force for reshoring American jobs.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A contrarian thesis that reframes AI from a job-destroyer to a driver of domestic job return.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: AI reshoring American jobs
quotes.text: And what cheap intelligence does is it makes those kinds of things affordable for small companies and individuals. So it stimulates demand.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A simple mental model—lowering the cost of intelligence expands the market by unlocking new buyers and use cases.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: AI reshoring American jobs
quotes.text: The other thing that it does is it allows people who are in those jobs to serve more people cheaply.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: An operational takeaway: use AI to increase per-worker leverage rather than assuming full role elimination.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: AI reshoring American jobs
quotes.text: And so it becomes much more cost-effective for American companies to hire people in the US.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A practical implication for leaders: AI can shift labor economics enough to change hiring location decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Hot take: AI reshoring American jobs
quotes.text: but I think it's quite lost in the conversation over whether AI will get rid of jobs.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A reminder to broaden strategy discussions beyond displacement to second-order effects like demand expansion and reshoring.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code for non-coders and local agents
quotes.text: I think people are truly sleeping on how good Claude Code is for non-coders.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Contrarian claim that terminal-based agents are underrated for non-technical users, reframing who these tools are for.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code for non-coders and local agents
quotes.text: You can give it something to do and it will go off and it'll run for 20 or 30 minutes and complete a task autonomously, agentically.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Actionable mental model: treat Claude Code like a long-running autonomous worker rather than a turn-by-turn chat assistant.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code for non-coders and local agents
quotes.text: But for example, you can download all your meeting notes and put it in a folder and just be like, "Okay, I want you to read every single one of my meeting notes and tell me..." Something that I do, for example, is, "Tell me all the time that I subtly avoided conflict."
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Concrete workflow for non-coders: point an agent at a local corpus and ask for behavioral pattern extraction.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code for non-coders and local agents
quotes.text: So it's not just stuffing everything into context, which is what you'd be doing with ChatGPT chat or a regular Claude chat. It's actually processing every single file that you give it.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Key distinction between local agents and chat UIs: file-by-file processing enables scalable analysis across large text sets.

quotes.topic_title: Claude Code for non-coders and local agents
quotes.text: And so I just downloaded War and Peace to my computer, which you can do because it's public domain. And then I had Claude read the first three chapters of War and Peace and pull out all of those descriptions, and then make a guide for itself for how to do character descriptions like Tolstoy.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Specific example of using a local agent to extract stylistic patterns from source material and generate a reusable writing guide.

quotes.topic_title: From chatboxes to delegation-first AI interfaces
quotes.text: all of the original AI apps were pasting a chat box into an existing UI.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights a common first-wave pattern in AI product design that teams can move beyond when building next-gen interfaces.

quotes.topic_title: From chatboxes to delegation-first AI interfaces
quotes.text: And the difference with Claude Code is you never look at the code. It's not meant for coding, it's not meant for coding by hand.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A sharp mental model shift from “AI-assisted editing” to “AI-driven execution,” implying different UX and workflow choices.

quotes.topic_title: From chatboxes to delegation-first AI interfaces
quotes.text: It's meant for you to say, "I want you to get something done," and it goes and does it.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Defines a delegation-first interface principle practitioners can apply when designing agentic products.

quotes.topic_title: From chatboxes to delegation-first AI interfaces
quotes.text: I think we're just getting to a point where for pretty much all the usual applications, AI is going to be good enough that we can get rid of the interfaces more or less where you're digging into all the things that it's actually doing and you're interleaved with its execution and you're more just like, "I'm delegating, it's going to go do it."
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete prediction and product strategy: reduce human-in-the-loop UI complexity and optimize for delegation and outcomes.

quotes.topic_title: From chatboxes to delegation-first AI interfaces
quotes.text: For the last three months, he hasn't touched a single line of front-end code, all Cursor and other tools he's using.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A specific real-world example showing how quickly teams can shift to AI-first development workflows.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AGI by autonomy leash and profitability
quotes.text: What I have noticed is that you can tell how much better AI is getting by how long a leash you can give it to do work.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A practical evaluation framework: measure model progress by the duration it can operate autonomously before needing human intervention.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AGI by autonomy leash and profitability
quotes.text: So I think a good definition of AGI is when does it become economically profitable for people to run agents indefinitely?
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A novel AGI definition grounded in real-world economics rather than benchmarks—continuous operation justified by ROI.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AGI by autonomy leash and profitability
quotes.text: So it just never turns off. It's a Claude Code that's always running, it's always doing something, you just never turn it off, and you don't need to because you know that it's worthwhile to keep it on.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete, memorable picture of “always-on” agents as the practical threshold for AGI-level usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AGI by autonomy leash and profitability
quotes.text: And I like the profitable thing, because if it costs a little bit of money and the bar is profitability, it has to actually be doing something useful for you to keep it on.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A countermeasure to “agent theater”: profitability forces continuous agents to deliver sustained, measurable value.

quotes.topic_title: Defining AGI by autonomy leash and profitability
quotes.text: It's interesting how the metaphor of a senior employee and autonomy and essentially the more autonomous they are, the less instruction you have to give, the less reviews you have to do, is also just directly correlated with how senior they are.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A useful mental model for managing agents: treat autonomy as “seniority,” with reduced oversight as capability increases.

quotes.topic_title: Debunking job-loss and “AI turns off brain” narratives
quotes.text: So for the doctors plus AI example, I think it's important to recognize that using AI is a skill.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Reframes AI outcomes as dependent on user competence, implying teams should train and measure AI skill rather than treat AI as a plug-and-play tool.

quotes.topic_title: Debunking job-loss and “AI turns off brain” narratives
quotes.text: But there's so many contexts that doctors need to make decisions and do things that it's really hard to take one study and make any conclusion about that.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A cautionary mental model for practitioners: avoid overgeneralizing from narrow benchmarks and evaluate AI in the real decision contexts that matter.

quotes.topic_title: Debunking job-loss and “AI turns off brain” narratives
quotes.text: I think it's really important to understand that in the history of technology, it has always been the case that you give up certain skills in order to get other ones.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Provides a tradeoff framework for assessing AI: expect skill substitution and judge the net leverage gained rather than only the skills lost.

quotes.topic_title: Debunking job-loss and “AI turns off brain” narratives
quotes.text: But I think writing is a worthwhile trade for having a slightly worse memory.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A memorable analogy that challenges “AI makes you dumber” narratives by highlighting that productivity tools often reduce one capability while increasing overall power.

quotes.topic_title: Debunking job-loss and “AI turns off brain” narratives
quotes.text: Credit cards have been around for a long time, so it takes a long time for technology like this to be adopted even in the best case.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete adoption example practitioners can use to calibrate timelines and plan for slower real-world rollout than hype suggests.

quotes.topic_title: Context engineering limits and “CEO benchmark” experiment
quotes.text: There's this real push now. Tobi from Spotify coined this term called "context engineering," which is getting the context to the model, the right context at the right time, is at least half the performance.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Introduces a practical framework—context engineering—as a major determinant of model performance beyond raw model capability.

quotes.topic_title: Context engineering limits and “CEO benchmark” experiment
quotes.text: But it's totally true, and that's a very, very hard problem to solve. It's not just a one- shot problem where it's gigantic context window and we're done.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Counters the common assumption that bigger context windows alone solve real-world AI reliability and usefulness.

quotes.topic_title: Context engineering limits and “CEO benchmark” experiment
quotes.text: I think if you're a CEO, or founder, or manager, it's really stunning how much of your job is just repeating yourself. And that is one of the best things about this AI, particularly AI revolution, is that you don't have to repeat yourself.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Actionable management insight: use AI to reduce repetitive communication and scale leadership intent.

quotes.topic_title: Context engineering limits and “CEO benchmark” experiment
quotes.text: And we've started to codify all of that into prompts that basically... It's not the same as mimicking me. It can't exactly say exactly what I'm going to say in a meeting, but it pushes my taste out to the edge so that writers who are not able to talk to me, by the time I see it, they've already talked to some simulation of a simulation of me. And that's incredibly powerful.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Concrete methodology: codify feedback into prompts to distribute a leader’s “taste” and decision standards across the team.

quotes.topic_title: What Every is: ideas, apps, and AI edge
quotes.text: I think it's newly enabled by AI, and we can talk about why. But the way that I typically talk about Every is we do ideas and apps at the edge of AI.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concise positioning framework: pair thought leadership (“ideas”) with shipping software (“apps”) to stay at the frontier.

quotes.topic_title: What Every is: ideas, apps, and AI edge
quotes.text: I think it's really important to do vibe checks and to call them vibe checks because they're about how does it feel to use this thing and how does it feel to use it for work for things that you would normally use it for in your job or in your life. Because I think that captures something that standard benchmarks just don't capture and really can't.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A practical evaluation methodology: complement benchmarks with real-work “vibe checks” to assess usefulness in context.

quotes.topic_title: What Every is: ideas, apps, and AI edge
quotes.text: And the best people to tell... to write a vibe check are people that are actually at the edge using it for stuff.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Actionable guidance on who should evaluate new models/tools: prioritize practitioners actively using them in real workflows.

quotes.topic_title: What Every is: ideas, apps, and AI edge
quotes.text: And so what we've found over time is we have... We love, we think the best writing and content about technology is from people that are actually using it and building with it.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A counterintuitive content/product strategy: credibility and insight come from building alongside writing, not commentary alone.

quotes.topic_title: What Every is: ideas, apps, and AI edge
quotes.text: And basically we bundle everything together. So you pay one price, and you get access to all of the software that we make, and we're constantly putting new stuff in the bundle.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete go-to-market/pricing model: bundle multiple AI tools under one subscription and keep adding new products.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting arm: helping companies become AI-first
quotes.text: We also do that, and that's the third leg of the stool in the business.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A simple business model framework: consulting as a stabilizing third revenue stream alongside other lines of business.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting arm: helping companies become AI-first
quotes.text: we spend a lot of time with big companies, where we teach them basically how to be AI-first.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Positions consulting as a repeatable transformation offering—helping enterprises shift operating principles to AI-first.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting arm: helping companies become AI-first
quotes.text: We train all the people on how to use AI.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights a practical adoption lever: scaling AI impact via organization-wide training, not just tooling.

quotes.topic_title: Consulting arm: helping companies become AI-first
quotes.text: That feels like a billion-dollar business right there.
quotes.speaker: Lenny Rachitsky
quotes.context: A market-size signal that AI adoption consulting for large organizations may be a major growth opportunity.

quotes.topic_title: AI operations lead and editorial workflow automation
quotes.text: One, and I think everyone should do this, is we have a head of AI operations. I sit with her once a week. And every time I'm doing something repetitively, we put it in a to-do list. And she's just constantly building prompts, and building workflows, and stuff like that so that I and everyone else on the team are just automating as much as possible.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete operating cadence for systematically turning repetitive work into reusable AI prompts/workflows via a dedicated role.

quotes.topic_title: AI operations lead and editorial workflow automation
quotes.text: And having an AI operations lead lets you basically identify those things and have them solved without people who are doing the work actually having to take time to do it, which I think makes it much more likely it happens.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Explains why centralizing automation work increases adoption: it removes the time/attention tax from frontline operators.

quotes.topic_title: AI operations lead and editorial workflow automation
quotes.text: There's always a trick with that, where it's like you have to make sure it gets used.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights the often-missed implementation risk: building internal AI tools is easy compared to driving consistent usage.

quotes.topic_title: AI operations lead and editorial workflow automation
quotes.text: The trick is it's not just building that. You also have to get Kate to be like, "Did you put this through the prompt yet," anytime someone gives her something.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A practical example of pairing automation with behavior change to embed AI workflows into day-to-day editorial processes.

quotes.topic_title: AI operations lead and editorial workflow automation
quotes.text: So one thing that we did, Nityesh, who's one of the engineers on Cora, built a Claude Code command that just uses that prompt, and checks through the entire code base for all the copy edits, and then creates a pull request on GitHub, and then sends the pull request to Kate.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A specific implementation pattern: operationalize a style-guide prompt as an engineering command that auto-generates PRs for review.

quotes.topic_title: Dan’s AI tool stack and Opus 4 judging ability
quotes.text: And what it has that really makes a difference still from Claude is it has memory. And I just love that. I've spent so much time yelling at ChatGPT about, "I need my writing to be punchy and concise." And it just knows that now.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights a practical advantage of models with memory: you can “train” them over time to match your personal style without re-explaining preferences.

quotes.topic_title: Dan’s AI tool stack and Opus 4 judging ability
quotes.text: So it doesn't have the same kind of gut. It's thinking about what you probably want hear too much.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A contrarian diagnosis of why LLM “judging” often fails: models optimize for user-pleasing responses rather than honest evaluation.

quotes.topic_title: Dan’s AI tool stack and Opus 4 judging ability
quotes.text: And Opus 4 has it. It's really wild. And I think that's super important because it opens up all these use cases where you might want to use a language model as a judge.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Introduces a key methodology shift—using an LLM as an evaluator/judge—which enables self-critique loops and higher-quality automation.

quotes.topic_title: Dan’s AI tool stack and Opus 4 judging ability
quotes.text: And one of the things that is so interesting is now, because it can judge things, part of its to-do list is, "Okay, I wrote three tweets. I'm going to judge whether I think these are any good," and then it can improve before it comes back to you.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Concrete example of an actionable workflow: generate multiple drafts, self-evaluate, then revise before presenting output to the user.

quotes.topic_title: Dan’s AI tool stack and Opus 4 judging ability
quotes.text: And that's just a huge, huge unlock, that we were struggling for three months to build this crazy system to try to get it to judge writing. And then Opus 4, just one-shotted it, and we're like, "Great, this product works. Let's start chipping it."
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Specific example/data point showing how model capability jumps can collapse months of engineering effort into a single promptable behavior.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think that AI may be one of the biggest force for reshoring American jobs.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A contrarian macro thesis that reframes AI from “job killer” to a driver of domestic hiring via cost and leverage effects.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: What cheap intelligence does is it makes those kinds of things affordable for small companies and individuals. So it stimulates demand.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A practical demand-side mental model: lowering the cost of “intelligence” expands the market for services previously limited to big budgets.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: I think people are truly sleeping on how good Claude Code is for non-coders.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Actionable tool insight: command-line agents aren’t just for engineers and can unlock high-leverage workflows for non-technical roles.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: But for example, you can download all your meeting notes and put it in a folder and just be like, "Okay, I want you to read every single one of my meeting notes and tell me..."
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A concrete workflow pattern—batch local files into a folder and delegate long-running analysis to an agent.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: So it's not just stuffing everything into context, which is what you'd be doing with ChatGPT chat or a regular Claude chat. It's actually processing every single file that you give it.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: A key methodology distinction: agentic tools can iteratively process large corpora beyond typical chat context limits.

quotes.topic_title: Compounding engineering with prompts and agent libraries
quotes.text: One of the things that we do that I think is really cool, and they basically invented this, I had nothing to do with this, is they invented the idea of compounding engineering. So basically, for every unit of work, you should make the next unit of work easier to do.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Defines a reusable mental model for building leverage into engineering work so effort compounds over time.

quotes.topic_title: Compounding engineering with prompts and agent libraries
quotes.text: Or you could spend a little bit of time being like... There's a sort of platonic ideal of a PRD. And what I'm going to do is write a prompt that can take my rambling thoughts and then turn that into a PRD.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Concrete example of investing once (a prompt) to repeatedly reduce future effort (PRD creation).

quotes.topic_title: Compounding engineering with prompts and agent libraries
quotes.text: And so finding those little speed-ups, where every time you're building something, you're making it easier to do that same thing next time, I think gets you a lot more leverage in your engineering team.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Actionable guidance to systematically look for repeatable workflow accelerators that increase team throughput.

quotes.topic_title: Compounding engineering with prompts and agent libraries
quotes.text: What they're using a lot of is Claude Code. So you can do slash commands in Claude Code, which are repeated prompts that you're doing.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Specific implementation detail: operationalizing reusable prompts as slash commands to standardize and speed up work.

quotes.topic_title: Compounding engineering with prompts and agent libraries
quotes.text: It's a GitHub. It's a GitHub GitHub-
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Practical storage/sharing mechanism for a team prompt library: keep it versioned and collaborative in GitHub.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-agent workflows and emerging agent tools
quotes.text: Another thing that they do, which I think is very cool, is they use a bunch of Claudes at once, but then they're also using three other agents.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Highlights a practical multi-agent workflow: run multiple instances of one model alongside other specialized agents.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-agent workflows and emerging agent tools
quotes.text: They did an S-tier through F-tier of AI agents, which I think is so funny.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Introduces a simple evaluation framework for comparing agent quality using a familiar tier-ranking system.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-agent workflows and emerging agent tools
quotes.text: And one of the things I really like about Charlie is that it lives in GitHub, so when you get a pull request, you can just be like, at Charlie, "Can you check this out?"
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Gives an actionable integration pattern: embed an agent directly in the developer workflow (PR review) to reduce friction.

quotes.topic_title: Multi-agent workflows and emerging agent tools
quotes.text: And that seems to work really well to have different agents that have maybe slightly different perspectives. It's like different people that have different perspectives and have different taste.
quotes.speaker: Dan Shipper
quotes.context: Offers a mental model for multi-agent setups: treat agents like a team with diverse viewpoints to improve outcomes.
